item.title: Chip shortage: Toyota to cut global production by 40%
item.description: The world's biggest carmaker will cut output in September, while VW warns it may have to make further cuts.

item.title: Stock markets sink on 'cocktail of worries'
item.description: Shares and oil prices fall as investors take fright over economic concerns, the spread of coronavirus, and the Taliban.

item.title: FTSE bosses earn 86 times more than average worker in 2020
item.description: The bosses of Britain's biggest public companies earned 86 times the average full-time wage last year.

item.title: Ultra Electronics deal unlikely to be rejected
item.description: The government is to investigate the takeover of Ultra Electronics, but its sale is unlikely to be stopped.

item.title: Rank Group racks up big losses after venues shut during lockdown
item.description: But Rank Group, which also owns casinos, says trading since reopening has exceeded expectations.

item.title: PCR testing ‘rip-off’: Watchdog warned government in April
item.description: The Competition and Markets Authority hits back at claims it was slow to react to consumers' concerns.

item.title: IMF suspends Afghanistan's access to funds
item.description: The move follows the Taliban's takeover, and lack of global agreement over who now governs Afghanistan.

item.title: Former Netflix staffers charged for making $3m from insider trading
item.description: The Wall Street regulator says confidential subscriber growth data was used in the alleged scheme.

item.title: 40 million T-Mobile customers hit by US data breach
item.description: More than 40 million T-Mobile customers have been hit by a US data breach.

item.title: Nando's hopes to reopen fully from Saturday after supply shortage
item.description: The chain had to shut about 50 restaurants due to food shortages thought to include its signature peri-peri chicken.

item.title: Northern English regions drive house price growth
item.description: Wales also records rapid rises as the UK sees property prices go up at the fastest rate for 17 years.

item.title: Price rises cool amid clothes and shoe discounting
item.description: The UK inflation rate fell by more than expected to 2% in July, down from 2.5% the previous month.

item.title: Scottish public spending deficit doubles to £36bn
item.description: Spending on public services rose to almost £100bn as revenue fell due to the Covid pandemic.

item.title: Taliban will not be able to access most Afghan central bank assets
item.description: Most of the country's financial reserves are held in the US where the Taliban will not be able to access them.

item.title: Franco Manca owner planning big UK and overseas expansion
item.description: Restaurant group Fulham Shore plans to open up to 150 new outlets amid continued strong trading.

item.title: CEO Secrets: Don't ask for all your funding up front
item.description: Don't ask for all your funding at once, says Zazuu CEO Kay Akinwunmi, but in smaller chunks.

item.title: Never mind going electric, where will we park?
item.description: UK roads are already jam-packed and that looks set to get worse as more people snap up EVs.

item.title: Just how hard is it to recycle a jumbo jet?
item.description: Thousands of aircraft were left on the tarmac due to Covid, and many will now be broken up for parts.

item.title: Would you let a robot lawyer defend you?
item.description: Why artificial intelligence is increasingly being used by the legal profession.

item.title: How can new technology protect outdoor workers?
item.description: Working outdoors in extreme heat can be deadly, new tech and better protection for workers could help.

item.title: How we can all get more high-quality sleep
item.description: The pandemic has led to a sharp increase in insomnia, but some firms are now helping their staff.

item.title: CEO Secrets: Foot Locker boss shares his advice

item.title: Sharing apps are booming but will the kindness continue?
item.description: The pandemic sparked a surge in activity for sharing apps like Olio but has the trend run its course?

item.title: Can technology help authors write a book?
item.description: Writing a novel is notoriously difficult, but technology may give the writer a helping hand.

item.title: The activist entrepreneurs running zero-waste shops
item.description: Environmentally conscious entrepreneurs explain the movement towards zero-waste lifestyles.

item.title: Why artificial intelligence is being used to write adverts
